heading.title: PART 12 DISCONTINUANCE, WITHDRAWAL, DISMISSAL AND SETTING ASIDE OF ORIGINATING PROCESS [rr 12.1–12.11]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 12 DISCONTINUANCE, WITHDRAWAL, DISMISSAL AND SETTING ASIDE OF ORIGINATING PROCESS [rr 12.1–12.11]

leg:heading.title: DISCONTINUANCE, WITHDRAWAL, DISMISSAL AND SETTING ASIDE OF ORIGINATING PROCESS [rr 12.1–12.11]

row.entry: This Division regulates the discontinuance of proceedings and its effect in relation to bringing further similar proceedings.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Withdrawal of appearance or pleading — Rules 12.5–12.6

row.entry: This Division sets out the circumstances in which appearances and defences may be withdrawn.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Dismissal of proceedings for lack of progress — Rules 12.7–12.10

row.entry: This Division permits the court to dismiss proceedings for want of prosecution.

entry.emph: Division 4 — Setting aside originating process — Rule 12.11

row.entry: This rule sets out the court’s power to set aside the service of originating process.
This Part applies to all courts in Sch 1 of the CPA: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.
The Part substantially reflects the former SCR Pts 21 and 40 and relevant provisions of Pts 5 and 11, as well as the similar provisions in DCR Pt 18 and LCR Pt 17.
Costs in favour of the discontinuing party ‥ [12.1.25]
Costs — normally ordered against discontinuing party ‥ [12.1.20]
Desirability of warning of dismissal application ‥ [12.7.25]
Dismissal for want of due progress ‥ [12.7.5]
Dismissal of cross-claim for want of prosecution ‥ [12.7.30]
Effect of dismissal for want of prosecution ‥ [12.7.40]
Grounds for applications to set aside ‥ [12.11.10]
Inactivity as a ground for dismissal ‥ [12.8.5]
Leave to discontinue –– failure to obtain ‥ [12.1.55]
Leave to discontinue –– terms of leave ‥ [12.1.60]
No right to appear on primary application ‥ [12.11.25]

Originating process — setting aside service of ‥ [r 12.11]
Stay of subsequent proceedings where costs unpaid ‥ [12.4.5]
Stay to secure costs of dismissal ‥ [r 12.10]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.1] r 12.1 Discontinuance of proceedings (cf SCR Part 21, rules 2 and 5; DCR Part 18, rule 1; LCR Part 17, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Discontinuance of proceedings (cf SCR Part 21, rules 2 and 5; DCR Part 18, rule 1; LCR Part 17, rule 1)

p.text: The plaintiff in any proceedings may, by filing a notice of discontinuance, discontinue the proceedings, either as to all claims for relief or as to all claims for relief so far as they concern a particular defendant:
with the consent of each other active party in the proceedings, or
with the leave of the court.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 11 November 2005; am Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 8 December 2006]
A notice of discontinuance:
must bear a certificate by the plaintiff, or by his or her solicitor, to the effect that the plaintiff does not represent any other person, and

except where it is filed with the leave of the court, must be accompanied by a notice from each party whose consent is required by subrule (1) to the effect that the party consents to the proceedings being discontinued in accordance with the notice of discontinuance.
[subr (2) am Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 11 November 2005]
If any such consent is given on terms, those terms are to be incorporated in the notice of consent.
If any party has not been served with the originating process, the plaintiff must file an affidavit to that effect.
For the purposes of this rule, proceedings on a cross-claim are taken to be different proceedings to the proceedings on the originating process and to proceedings on any other cross-claim.
The approved form is Form 33 : Notice of discontinuance.
Legislation cited in [12.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.8.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 91.

A claimant party (either plaintiff or cross claimant) who does not wish to pursue any claim to relief against a particular defendant must either discontinue under the present rule or consent to judgment: Fox v Star Newspaper Co Ltd [1898] 1 QB 636; [1900] AC 19 ; Phillips v Ellinson Bros Pty Ltd (1941) 65 CLR 221 at 228; [1941] ALR 340 ; Tamsett v Conditionaire Engineering Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 511 ; Schipp v Herfords Pty Ltd [1975] 1 NSWLR 412 at 423 ; Humphrey v Collier [1946] VLR 391 at 404 . A claimant party that intends only to forgo particular causes of action, or particular remedies, may take any of three possible courses of action — namely (i) seek appropriate leave to amend, (ii) discontinue the particular claims for relief in accordance with the terms of the present rule (ie either by consent or with leave), or (iii) apply for the dismissal of the relevant part of the claim for relief under UCPR r 29.8 . Dismissal under that rule without the court undertaking a hearing on the merits would not necessarily preclude the commencement of later proceedings for the same relief: see CPA s 91 . (In this respect the CPA contradicts the consequence that would otherwise follow from a formal order of dismissal — which can operate to give rise to res judicata or issue estoppel: see Barber v Staffordshire County Council [1996] 2 All ER 748 at 756 ; SCF Finance Co Ltd v Masri (No 3) [1987] QB 1028 at 1047 .)

The expression “claim for relief” tends to be regarded as meaning a cause of action rather than a claim for a particular form of relief. On this basis, neither consent nor leave is required where a plaintiff merely elects to forgo one of the alternative remedies available for the pleaded cause of action: Morely London Developments v Rightside Properties (1973) 117 Sol Jo 876 (damages instead of specific performance); cf Newmont Pty Ltd v Laverton Nickel NL [1981] 1 NSWLR 215 (where there was an alternative cause of action for common law damages and leave was refused).

level.toc-caption: [12.1.20] Costs — normally ordered against discontinuing party

p.text: Legislation cited in [12.1.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.19.

heading.title: Costs — normally ordered against discontinuing party

p.text: A party who discontinues must ordinarily pay the other party's costs of the discontinued claim to relief, unless the court otherwise orders, or the notice of discontinuance makes some other provision: see UCPR r 42.19 . Circumstances in which it may be appropriate to make a different costs order include:

where both parties have acted reasonably but the proceedings have been rendered futile by circumstances beyond their control: Newcastle Wallsend Coal Co Pty Ltd v Industrial Relations Commission (NSW) [2006] NSWCA 129; BC200603855 at [23] and [39] .

level.toc-caption: [12.1.25] Costs in favour of the discontinuing party

heading.title: Costs in favour of the discontinuing party

p.text: A plaintiff will not usually be granted leave to discontinue “on terms” that an order for costs be made against the defendant: Hill v Copeland [1999] NSWSC 632; BC9903587 ; Dohrmann v A-G (Vic) [1995] 1 VR 274 at 277; BC9401053 (no power to order a defendant to pay the discontinuing party's costs); Foukkare v Angreb Pty Ltd [2006] NSWCA 335; BC200609700 (offer to discontinue on terms that cost be determined by the court). But there are cases where such an order may be justified, despite judicial reluctance to explore costs issues in undetermined proceedings: see [42.1.55] (costs of compromised proceedings) and [42.7.10] (costs of interlocutory proceedings) and also JT Stratford & Son Ltd v Lindley (No 2) [1969]3 All ER 1122; [1969] 1 WLR 1547 at 1553 ; Australian Securities Commission v Aust-Home Investments Ltd (1993) 44 FCR 194 at 201; 116 ALR 523 ; Aussie Red Equipment Pty Ltd v Antsent Pty Ltd [2001] FCA 1641; BC200107235 and One.Tel Ltd v DCT (2000) 101 FCR 548; 171 ALR 227; [2000] FCA 270; BC200000891 .
A discontinuing party may be relieved of costs (or even awarded costs) where:

the discontinuing plaintiff has obtained practical success in the litigation: Garwolin Nominees Pty Ltd v Statewide Building Society [1984] VR 469 ; Telstra Corp Ltd v Australian Telecommunications Authority (VSC, Hayne J, No 14/93, 30 June 1994, unreported, BC9405104); Australian Securities Commission v Aust-Home Investments Ltd , above; Cummins v Australian Jockey Club Ltd [2009] NSWSC 254; BC200902257 at [32] and [34] ;

where the defendant has acted unreasonably in its opposition to the plaintiff's claim: Reid v Shearan [2002] NSWSC 902; BC200205818 (defendant ordered to pay half plaintiff's costs); Altium Ltd v APGF Property Ltd [2010] NSWSC 732; BC201004658 (landlord defendant insisting on unreasonable “make good” obligations, drawing on full security amount in excess of “make good” costs and refusing to provide an undertaking in relation to the amount of the excess)
where the defendant’s conduct has caused unnecessary costs to be incurred: Bitannia Pty Ltd v Parkline Constructions Pty Ltd [2009] NSWCA 32; BC200901045 at [62] .
Legislation cited in [12.1.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 19.1.

An amendment to substitute a new defendant for an existing party operates to remove the first party from the proceedings without any need for the filing of a formal discontinuance under the present rule: New South Wales Amateur Soccer Federation Ltd v Gemallas [1999] NSWCA 86; BC9901409 . Neither does amendment (made with leave under CPA s 64 or pursuant to UCPR r 19.1 ) which has the effect of deleting a cause of action require a separate notice of discontinuance.

Individual co-plaintiffs may discontinue where they rely upon separate, or alternative, causes of action: McLachlan v de Vere [2006] NSWSC 959; BC200607701 at [10]-[11] per White J; King v Sunday Pictorial Newspapers Ltd (1924) 41 TLR 229. Individual co-plaintiffs who sue on a joint cause of action cannot discontinue. A co-plaintiff who does not wish to prosecute the proceedings may be added as a defendant: Re Matthews [1905] 2 Ch 460 .

It will rarely be appropriate to grant leave to discontinue where the proceedings have proceeded to a contested hearing: Stahlschmidt v Walford (1879) 4 QBD 217 ; Re Alpha Co Ltd [1903] 1 Ch 203 ; Stevens v Theatres Ltd [1903] 1 Ch 860. However, in Brown v Parker [1961] WAR 194 , leave to discontinue was granted after hearing, but before judgment, where legislative amendments had increased the amount of recoverable damages. Similarly, in Castanho v Brown & Root (UK) Ltd [1981] AC 557; [1981] 1 All ER 143 , a foreign resident was granted leave to discontinue English proceedings in order to sue in Texas, notwithstanding the receipt of interim payments in the English proceedings. When a claim for specific performance and a claim for common law damages have been joined in the one proceeding, the court will not, if specific performance is refused, grant the plaintiff leave to discontinue the claim for damages in order to facilitate an appeal on the claim for specific performance: Newmont Pty Ltd v Laverton Nickel NL [1981] 1 NSWLR 215 .
Legislation cited in [12.1.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 82, s 84(3)(b).
Where a plaintiff has received interim payments under CPA s 82 , the court may require repayment as a term of the grant of leave to discontinue: see CPA s 84(3)(b) .

The court will normally allow a plaintiff to discontinue. Leave may be refused where the discontinuance would cause an injustice to the defendant. Relevant injustice arises if the discontinuance would deprive the defendant of some advantage that the defendant has already gained in the litigation. But even in such a case, leave to discontinue may be granted on terms that preserve any such advantage: Covell Matthews v French Wools Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 591 at 594; [1977] 1 WLR 876 at 879 ; affirmed in [1978] 1 WLR 1477; [1978] 2 All ER 800; Young, Austen & Young Ltd v British Medical Assn [1977] 2 All ER 884; [1977] 1 WLR 881 ; SCI Operations Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1984) 2 FCR 113; 53 ALR 283 ; Ritz Hotel Ltd v Charles of the Ritz Ltd (No 8) (1987) 12 IPR 75 . Leave to discontinue against one of several defendants may be refused where the discontinuance might otherwise affect the rights of contribution between them: Trade Practices Commission v Manfal Pty Ltd (No 3) (in liq) (1991) 33 FCR 382; 105 ALR 520 .

level.toc-caption: [12.1.55] Leave to discontinue –– failure to obtain

heading.title: Leave to discontinue –– failure to obtain

p.text: A notice of discontinuance filed without leave or consent may constitute an abuse of the process of the court. The court may order such a purported notice to be removed from the file. See also Castanho v Brown & Root (UK) Ltd [1981] AC 557; [1981] 1 All ER 143 ; Packer v Meagher [1984] 3 NSWLR 486 ; Borthwick-Coleman v Lonergan [1993] 2 Qd R 517 at 520 .

level.toc-caption: [12.1.60] Leave to discontinue –– terms of leave

heading.title: Leave to discontinue –– terms of leave

p.text: The court may grant leave to discontinue on terms. As a general proposition, terms imposed on the grant of leave to discontinue must operate against the party applying for leave. Commonly, the terms will relate to the payment of the costs of the proceedings or prevent the plaintiff from bringing subsequent proceedings: Hess v Labouchere (1898) 14 TLR 350 ; Fox v Star Newspaper Co Ltd [1898] 1 QB 636 at 639; [1900] AC 19 at 20 ; Robertson v Purdey [1906] 2 Ch 615 ; Heimann v Commonwealth (1940) 58 WN (NSW) 2 ; American International Group Inc v London American International Corp Ltd [1982] FSR 441 . Terms may include the provision of security for costs if the same claim is pursued in subsequent proceedings: Sharpe v Wren [1917] QWN 45; [1917] St R Qd 317 .

level.toc-caption: [12.1.65] Offer of compromise — discontinuance after acceptance of limited offer

p.text: Legislation cited in [12.1.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.26, r 42.13A.

heading.title: Offer of compromise — discontinuance after acceptance of limited offer

p.text: An offer of compromise under UCPR r 20.26 can be made in relation to any claim for relief in proceedings. Where such an offer relates only to some of the causes of action pleaded, a plaintiff may accept the offer and abandon the other causes of action. As a result of the acceptance of the offer, the plaintiff will normally be entitled to an order for costs –– unless the court makes a contrary order: see UCPR r 42.13A . The court retains its general costs discretion and this avoids the possibility of the inflexible result that followed acceptance of a limited payment into court in Hudson v Elmbridge Borough Council [1991] 1 WLR 880.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.2] r 12.2 Discontinuance of claim by leave (cf SCR Part 21, rules 2 and 5; DCR Part 18, rule 1; LCR Part 17, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Discontinuance of claim by leave (cf SCR Part 21, rules 2 and 5; DCR Part 18, rule 1; LCR Part 17, rule 1)

p.text: [r 12.2 rep Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 11 November 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.3] r 12.3 Effect of discontinuance (cf SCR Part 21, rule 7; DCR Part 18, rule 7; LCR Part 17, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Effect of discontinuance (cf SCR Part 21, rule 7; DCR Part 18, rule 7; LCR Part 17, rule 8)

p.text: A discontinuance of proceedings with respect to a plaintiff’s claim for relief does not prevent the plaintiff from claiming the same relief in fresh proceedings.
Subrule (1) is subject to the terms of any consent to the discontinuance or of any leave to discontinue.

Discontinuance does not alter the status of the parties nor prevent subsequent applications being made in the proceedings: Orbell v Bundaleer Nursing Home Pty Ltd [1988] Qd R 152; Gold Reefs of Western Australia Ltd v Dawson [1897] 1 Ch 115 . Thus, an application may be made for leave to withdraw notice of discontinuance: Fowler v Renmark and Paringa District Hospital Inc (1988) 51 SASR 506 . Similarly, discontinuance will not affect any rights that have accrued to the other parties in the course of the litigation. A permanent injunction or undertaking will continue in force, notwithstanding discontinuance: Apple Computer Inc v Popiolek [1984] VR 156 ; Ellendale Pty Ltd v Graham Matthews Pty Ltd (1986) 11 FCR 347; 65 ALR 275 . A defendant may pursue an enquiry as to damages where a plaintiff had obtained an interlocutory injunction and given the usual undertaking as to damages: Newcomen v Coulson (1878) 9 Ch D 459 .
Legislation cited in [12.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.1(5).

Discontinuance does not bar subsequent proceedings, nor even an application to revive the proceedings by setting aside the discontinuance –– unless the discontinuance was on terms that no new proceedings would be brought: The Kronprinz (1887) 12 App Cas 256 at 262 ; KBRV Resort Operations Pty Ltd (t/as Kingfisher Bay Resort & Village) v Chilcott (2001) 51 NSWLR 516; [2001] NSWCA 116; BC200102124 ; Lawson v Wallace [1968] 3 NSWLR 82. However, delay in the commencement of subsequent proceedings may provide a separate ground of defence in those proceedings: Reid v London & North Staffordshire Fire Insurance Co (1883) 49 LT 468 . In some circumstances, discontinuance may operate as an election and prevent a party from subsequently raising an inconsistent allegation: Reid v London & North Staffordshire Fire Insurance Co (1883) 49 LT 468 (affirmation of a contract). The doctrine of Anshun estoppel (see Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun Pty Ltd (No 1) (1980) 147 CLR 35; 33 ALR 248; BC8000125 ) has no application where the plaintiff has commenced earlier litigation against the defendant but has, with the court's leave, discontinued that litigation rather than presenting it to a conclusion by judgment or settlement: Running Pigmy Productions Pty Ltd v AMP General Insurance Co Ltd [2001] NSWSC 431; BC200102880 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 12.4] r 12.4 Stay of further proceedings to secure costs of discontinued proceedings (cf SCR Part 21, rule 8; DCR Part 18, rule 8; LCR Part 17, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Stay of further proceedings to secure costs of discontinued proceedings (cf SCR Part 21, rule 8; DCR Part 18, rule 8; LCR Part 17, rule 9)

p.text: If:
as a consequence of the discontinuance of proceedings, a plaintiff is liable to pay the costs of another party in relation to those proceedings, and

before payment of the costs, the plaintiff commences further proceedings against that other party on the same or substantially the same cause of action as that on which the former proceedings were commenced,
the court may stay the further proceedings until those costs are paid and may make such consequential orders as it thinks fit.
See also section 67 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 as to the terms on which a stay may be granted, and rule 42.19 as to costs payable in relation to discontinued proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [12.4.5] Stay of subsequent proceedings where costs unpaid

heading.title: Stay of subsequent proceedings where costs unpaid

p.text: As a general rule, the court will grant a stay where the circumstances are within this rule: Re Payne (1883) 23 Ch D 288 ; Martin v Beauchamp (1883) 25 Ch D 12 ; McCabe v Bank of Ireland (1889) 14 App Cas 413 ; cf Re United Service Assn [1901] 1 Ch 97 ; Bowen v Hickey (1958) 78 WN (NSW) 820 ; Thames Investment & Securities v Benjamin [1984] 1 WLR 1381 . However, the matter is discretionary and the court may consider the defendant sufficiently protected by a right to set-off the costs of the earlier proceedings: Re United Service Assn [1901] 1 Ch 97 ; or if there is legal aid in the second action which will guarantee the recovery of costs to the successful party: Hutchinson v Nominal Defendant [1972] 1 NSWLR 443 ; but cf Dunbee Ltd v Gilman & Co (Aust) Pty Ltd [1969] 1 NSWR 406; (1968) 89 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 259 .
